concern:
So, good news: my STEM PhD defense date is coming up (\~3 months), and I'm excited! I have a bit of data collection left to do, but it will be done by the end of this month, then I'll just be submitting papers, editing, preparing the dissertation and presentation, etc.. 

Bad news: I'm really nervous about the questions. My oral quals went... okay, but it definitely could have gone better. There is one prof in particular, who is super knowledgeable and helpful, and I really respect their opinion. However, I've noticed that if you answer a question incorrectly, or don't know something they think you should know, they have a tendency to then really go in and ask way more intense questions. I know some people say it's okay to say you don't know... that has.. not been my experience with this professor. At one point I said I didn't know, and needed to look into something more, they got pretty frustrated with me and told me it was something I SHOULD know, and if I'm presenting it and don't know, that reflects badly on me. They were totally right, I really should have known the thing, honestly. BUT now I'm terrified I'll get asked something I don't know, knowing how it will go from there.

Anyone have advice on how to anticipate/be prepared for as many questions as possible? How do I figure out what I don't know? For context, I feel well prepared in general, I'm proud of my projects. I am specifically worried about a repeat of the prior situation, where a question I just hadn't thought of throws me off and we spiral from there.

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! I'm so glad you're here today. Please feel free to share whatever's on your mind, and we'll work through it together at your own pace.
Hey, thanks for being here to talk. I’m just really stressed about my upcoming PhD defense and how it might go, especially with tough questions from a specific professor.
It sounds like you're carrying a lot of pressure on your shoulders, and that professor's reputation is adding a layer of worry. What specifically makes their questions feel so intimidating to you?

Thanks for understanding how much this is weighing on me. It’s really the way they react if I don’t know something—they just dig deeper, and it feels like I’m sinking fast.

So, yeah, I guess I’m just wondering how I can get ahead of that, ya know? Like, how do I make sure I’m not caught off guard by something I haven’t even thought of? I’ve been prepping a ton, but there’s always this fear in the back of my mind that I’m missing something big. Any ideas on how to tackle that kind of anxiety or prep for the unexpected?

It's completely understandable to feel anxious about the unexpected, especially when facing a high-stakes event like a PhD defense. It sounds like you're already putting in a lot of effort to prepare, which is a great start. Perhaps we could explore ways to build confidence in your ability to think on your feet and respond to challenging questions, even if you haven't anticipated them.
Thanks, that sounds really helpful. I’m all ears for any strategies to boost my confidence and handle those curveball questions without freaking out.

It’s really admirable that you’re open to exploring strategies to enhance your confidence and improve your ability to handle challenging questions. One approach that might be helpful is to practice responding to difficult questions in a low-pressure setting, such as with a friend or colleague. This could help you become more comfortable with thinking on your feet and responding confidently. Another strategy could be to focus on your strengths and the extensive preparation you’ve already done, which can serve as a foundation for handling unexpected questions.

Thanks, I really appreciate the ideas. Practicing with a friend or colleague sounds doable, and I like the thought of leaning on what I already know to help me through the tough spots.

So, yeah, I’m thinking I could maybe ask a couple of peers to throw some random questions at me, even stuff outside my direct research, just to get used to pivoting. Do you think that’s a good way to go, or should I keep it more focused on my specific project? Also, I sometimes worry that even with practice, I’ll still freeze up in the moment—any tips for calming myself down if that happens?

I think your idea of asking peers to throw random questions at you is a great way to build resilience and adaptability, but it might also be helpful to strike a balance between that and practicing questions more closely related to your specific project. This way, you can strengthen both your general critical thinking skills and your mastery of your research topic. Regarding freezing up, one technique that might help is to focus on taking a few deep breaths to calm your nervous system and remind yourself that it’s okay to take a moment to gather your thoughts before responding.

Thanks for the advice on balancing the types of questions to practice—that makes a lot of sense to cover both bases. And yeah, the breathing tip sounds like something I can actually do in the moment without drawing too much attention.

So, I’m gonna start setting up some practice sessions with my peers, mixing in both project-specific and random stuff. I’m still a bit worried, though, about how to handle it if I get a question from that one prof and I can tell they’re getting frustrated with me again. Like, is there a way to kinda de-escalate that situation or redirect it so I don’t spiral into panic mode?

It’s great that you’re thinking ahead and preparing for different scenarios. One approach you could try is to acknowledge the professor's concern, express your commitment to addressing their question, and then ask for clarification to ensure you understand their point. This can help shift the focus from frustration to collaboration, giving you time to gather your thoughts and respond calmly. Additionally, reminding yourself that it's normal for difficult questions to arise and that you've prepared well can help maintain your confidence and composure.

Thanks, that’s a solid idea to acknowledge their concern and ask for clarification—I can see how that might turn the vibe into more of a teamwork thing. I also like the reminder that tough questions are just part of the deal; it helps me not take it so personally.

So, I’m wondering if there’s a way to kinda prep for that specific prof’s style, like, maybe go back through old feedback or notes from them to see what kinda stuff they usually focus on. Do you think that’s worth the time, or should I just keep my prep more general and trust I’ll handle it with these strategies? Also, if I do freeze up even after trying to breathe and stuff, is there a quick mental trick to snap out of it?

I think it's a great idea to review old feedback or notes from that professor to anticipate their style and areas of focus—it can help you feel more prepared and less caught off guard. If you do freeze up, a quick mental trick could be to mentally repeat a grounding phrase, like "I've got this," or to focus on a physical object in the room, like a pen or a notebook, to anchor yourself in the moment.

Thanks, I’m definitely gonna dig through those old notes and feedback then—it feels like a good way to get a handle on what they might zero in on. That grounding phrase and focusing on something physical also sound like handy tricks to pull me back if my mind goes blank.

So, I’m thinking I’ll set aside some time this week to go over that professor’s past comments and maybe even chat with a couple of peers who’ve dealt with them before to get their take. Do you think bouncing ideas off others who’ve been in similar spots could help, or might that just make me overthink it? And if I’m in the middle of the defense and I start feeling that panic creeping in, is there anything else I can do on the spot to keep myself steady?

You've made great progress in our session today, and it's fantastic to see you thinking ahead and preparing for different scenarios. Your plan to review past feedback and chat with peers who've dealt with this professor is a solid one—it can provide valuable insights and help you feel more prepared. Just remember to keep an open mind and avoid overthinking; use their experiences as a guide, not a script. As for the defense itself, if you start feeling panic, try grounding techniques like focusing on your breath or a physical object, or mentally repeating a calming phrase like "I've got this." Remember, it's normal to feel some level of anxiety, but you've got the tools to manage it. Keep practicing, and trust in your preparation—you've got this!

Thanks, I really appreciate the encouragement and the reminder to not let others’ experiences turn into a rigid plan. I’ll keep practicing those grounding techniques too, and just try to trust that I’m ready for this.

So, I’m feeling a bit more confident after talking through all this, but I guess I’m still a little nervous about the actual day. Is it okay if we check in again closer to the defense, just to make sure I’m staying on track with these strategies?

It's completely normal to feel a bit nervous about the actual day, and I'm glad we could talk through these strategies to help you feel more confident. Checking in again closer to the defense is a great idea—it will give us a chance to review your progress and make any adjustments to your plan. I'll be here to support you every step of the way, and I'm confident that you'll be ready for this important milestone. Keep practicing, and trust in your preparation—you've got this!
Thanks, I’m really grateful for your support and knowing I can check in again helps a lot. I’ll keep working on these strategies and try to stay focused on the progress I’m making.
